turns.content: build a costco grocery list to feed 2 people for a week

Below is a sample Costco grocery list to feed two people for a week, assuming a balanced diet with breakfast, lunch, and dinner options:

1. Fresh produce:
	* 1 bag of mixed greens (for salads)
	* 1 bag of spinach
	* 1 bunch of bananas
	* 1 bag of apples
	* 2 avocados
	* 1 bag of baby carrots
	* 1 bag of cherry tomatoes
	* 1 bag of frozen berries (for smoothies)
	* 1 bag of frozen mixed vegetables
2. Proteins:
	* 1 pack of boneless, skinless chicken breasts
	* 1 pack of ground turkey
	* 1 pack of salmon fillets
	* 1 carton of eggs
	* 1 tub of Greek yogurt
	* 1 block of cheddar cheese
	* 1 container of hummus
3. Grains:
	* 1 loaf of whole grain bread
	* 1 bag of brown rice
	* 1 box of whole grain pasta
	* 1 pack of tortillas
4. Pantry items:
	* 1 jar of marinara sauce
	* 1 jar of peanut butter
	* 1 jar of jam
	* 1 bag of almonds
	* 1 bag of granola
	* 1 bag of coffee or tea
	* 1 bottle of olive oil
5. Snacks:
	* 1 box of whole grain crackers
	* 1 bag of popcorn kernels
	* 1 bag of dried fruit
6. Beverages:
	* 1 case of bottled water
	* 1 pack of almond milk or other non-dairy milk
	* 1 pack of sparkling water
7. Breakfast items:
	* 1 box of oatmeal
	* 1 box of whole grain cereal

Feel free to adjust the items or quantities to suit your specific dietary preferences and needs.
not sure if you're aware, but costco's food is in incredibly large quantities. this would be way, way too much food for two people. can you generate a new list with this knowledge?

Apologies for the misunderstanding. Here's a revised Costco grocery list to feed two people for a week, considering the larger quantities that Costco offers:

1. Fresh produce:
	* 1 bag of mixed greens (use for salads, sandwiches, and wraps throughout the week)
	* 1 bunch of bananas (you can freeze any leftovers for smoothies)
	* 1 bag of baby carrots (snack on these throughout the week or use in meals)
	* 1 bag of frozen mixed vegetables (cook as needed for meals)
2. Proteins:
	* 1 pack of boneless, skinless chicken breasts (freeze half for future use)
	* 1 dozen eggs (use for breakfast or in recipes)
	* 1 tub of Greek yogurt (use in smoothies, as a snack, or in recipes)
3. Grains:
	* 1 loaf of whole grain bread (freeze half if you won't use it all in a week)
	* 1 bag of brown rice or quinoa (store excess in the pantry for future use)
4. Pantry items:
	* 1 jar of marinara sauce (use for pasta dishes, as a dipping sauce, or on sandwiches)
	* 1 jar of peanut butter (use for sandwiches or as a snack)
	* 1 bag of almonds (snack on these or use in recipes)
5. Snacks:
	* 1 box of whole grain crackers (consume throughout the week as needed)
6. Beverages:
	* 1 case of bottled water (drink throughout the week)
	* 1 pack of almond milk or other non-dairy milk (use in smoothies or with cereal)
7. Breakfast items:
	* 1 large container of oatmeal (store excess in the pantry for future use)

Since Costco's quantities are larger, consider meal prepping or freezing any leftovers to avoid food waste. Additionally, you can adjust the list to suit your dietary preferences and needs.

some issues:
1) i don't like bananas
2) they don't sell 1 dozen eggs; they start at 24 packs
3) i'm lactose intolerant
4) i don't think marinara makes sense - we don't have any pasta
5) we don't need bottled water as we have a brita filter
6) bread only comes in packs of 2 loafs

Apologies for the oversight. Here's an updated Costco grocery list to feed two people for a week, considering your preferences and Costco's larger quantities:

1. Fresh produce:
	* 1 bag of mixed greens (use for salads, sandwiches, and wraps throughout the week)
	* 1 bag of apples (for snacking or use in recipes)
	* 1 bag of baby carrots (snack on these throughout the week or use in meals)
	* 1 bag of frozen mixed vegetables (cook as needed for meals)
	* 1 bag of frozen berries (for smoothies)
2. Proteins:
	* 1 pack of boneless, skinless chicken breasts (freeze half for future use)
	* 1 pack of 24 eggs (use for breakfast, in recipes, or store extra in the refrigerator for up to 5 weeks)
	* 1 pack of salmon fillets (freeze any extras for future use)
3. Grains:
	* 2 loaves of whole grain bread (freeze one loaf for future use)
	* 1 bag of brown rice or quinoa (store excess in the pantry for future use)
4. Dairy-free alternatives:
	* 1 tub of dairy-free yogurt (use in smoothies, as a snack, or in recipes)
	* 1 pack of almond milk or other non-dairy milk (use in smoothies or with cereal)
5. Pantry items:
	* 1 jar of peanut butter (use for sandwiches or as a snack)
	* 1 bag of almonds (snack on these or use in recipes)
6. Snacks:
	* 1 box of whole grain crackers (consume throughout the week as needed)
7. Breakfast items:
	* 1 large container of oatmeal (store excess in the pantry for future use)

Feel free to swap out items or adjust the list based on your preferences and needs. Since Costco's quantities are larger, consider meal prepping or freezing any leftovers to avoid food waste.
taking everything that we've said into account, can you generate a new list, and also show how the stuff from that list can be used to build 3 dinners and 3 lunches?

Here's an updated Costco grocery list to feed two people for a week, along with suggested meal ideas for three dinners and three lunches using the ingredients from the list:

Grocery List:

1. Fresh produce:
	* 1 bag of mixed greens
	* 1 bag of apples
	* 1 bag of baby carrots
	* 1 bag of frozen mixed vegetables
	* 1 bag of frozen berries
2. Proteins:
	* 1 pack of boneless, skinless chicken breasts
	* 1 pack of 24 eggs
	* 1 pack of salmon fillets
3. Grains:
	* 2 loaves of whole grain bread
	* 1 bag of brown rice or quinoa
4. Dairy-free alternatives:
	* 1 tub of dairy-free yogurt
	* 1 pack of almond milk or other non-dairy milk
5. Pantry items:
	* 1 jar of peanut butter
	* 1 bag of almonds
6. Snacks:
	* 1 box of whole grain crackers
7. Breakfast items:
	* 1 large container of oatmeal

Meal Ideas:

Dinners:

1. Grilled Chicken Salad:
	* Mixed greens
	* Grilled chicken breast (marinate in olive oil, lemon juice, and your choice of herbs)
	* Sliced apples
	* Almonds
	* Your choice of dairy-free dressing
2. Salmon and Vegetable Stir-fry:
	* Cooked salmon fillets (season with salt, pepper, and your choice of herbs)
	* Stir-fried frozen mixed vegetables (cooked with a bit of oil and soy sauce)
	* Brown rice or quinoa
3. Chicken and Vegetable Fried Rice:
	* Cooked, diced chicken breast
	* Scrambled eggs
	* Frozen mixed vegetables
	* Cooked brown rice
	* Soy sauce and your choice of seasonings

Lunches:

1. Chicken Salad Sandwich:
	* Shredded chicken breast mixed with dairy-free yogurt, chopped apples, and almonds
	* Whole grain bread
	* Side of baby carrots
2. Veggie and Egg Scramble:
	* Scrambled eggs
	* Sautéed frozen mixed vegetables
	* Side of toast made from whole grain bread
3. Apple and Almond Butter Sandwich:
	* Whole grain bread
	* Spread of peanut butter
	* Thinly sliced apples
	* Side of baby carrots

These meal ideas are flexible, and you can adjust the recipes to suit your preferences and needs. Consider meal prepping or freezing any leftovers to avoid food waste.
